id.desc: Component ID, not specified by default. If specified, it can be used to refer the component in option or API.

name.desc:
Series name used for displaying in [tooltip][0] and filtering with [legend][1], or updating data and configuration with setOption.

[0]: #tooltip
[1]: #legend

zlevel.desc: zlevel value of all graphical elements in . zlevel is used to make layers with Canvas. Graphical elements with different zlevel values will be placed in different Canvases, which is a common optimization technique. We can put those frequently changed elements (like those with animations) to a separate zlevel. Notice that too many Canvases will increase memory cost, and should be used carefully on mobile phones to avoid crash. Canvases with bigger zlevel will be placed on Canvases with smaller zlevel.

z.desc: z value of all graphical elements in , which controls order of drawing graphical components. Components with smaller z values may be overwritten by those with larger z values. z has a lower priority to zlevel, and will not create new Canvas.

left.desc: Distance between treemap component and the left side of the container. left value can be instant pixel value like 20; it can also be a percentage value relative to container width like '20%'; and it can also be 'left', 'center', or 'right'. If the left value is set to be 'left', 'center', or 'right', then the component will be aligned automatically based on position.

top.desc: Distance between treemap component and the top side of the container. top value can be instant pixel value like 20; it can also be a percentage value relative to container width like '20%'; and it can also be 'top', 'middle', or 'bottom'. If the left value is set to be 'top', 'middle', or 'bottom', then the component will be aligned automatically based on position.

right.desc: Distance between treemap component and the right side of the container. right value can be instant pixel value like 20; it can also be a percentage value relative to container width like '20%'. Adaptive by default.

bottom.desc: Distance between treemap component and the bottom side of the container. bottom value can be instant pixel value like 20; it can also be a percentage value relative to container width like '20%'. Adaptive by default.

squareRatio.desc: The expected square ratio. Layout would approach the ratio as close as possible. It defaults to be the golden ratio: 0.5 * (1 + Math.sqrt(5)).

leafDepth.desc: When leafDepth is set, the feature "drill down" is enabled, which means when clicking a tree node, this node will be set as root and its children will be shown. leafDepth represents how many levels are shown at most. For example, when leafDepth is set to 1, only one level will be shown. leafDepth is null/undefined by default, which means that "drill down" is disabled. **An example about drill down:** 暂时无法显示

drillDownIcon.desc: Marker when the node is able to be drilled down.

roam.desc:
Whether to enable dragging roam (move and zoom). Optional values are: 

* false: roam is disabled.
* 'scale' or 'zoom': zoom only.
* 'move' or 'pan': move (translation) only.
* true: both zoom and move (translation) are avaliable.

nodeClick.desc:
The behaviour when clicking a node. Optional values are: 

* false: Do nothing after clicked.
* 'zoomToNode': Zoom to clicked node.
* 'link': If there is [link][0] in node data, do hyperlink jump after clicked.



[0]: #series-treemap.data.link

zoomToNodeRatio.desc:
The treemap will be auto zoomed to a appropriate ratio when a node is clicked (when [nodeClick][0] is set as 'zoomToNode' and no drill down happens). This configuration item indicates the ratio.

[0]: #series-treemap.nodeClick

visualDimension.desc:
treemap is able to map any dimensions of data to visual. The value of [series-treemap.data][0] can be an array. And each item of the array represents a "dimension". visualDimension specifies the dimension on which visual mapping will be performed. About visual encoding, see details in [series-treemap.levels][1]. 

> Tps: In treemap, > visualDimension>  attribute could appear in more than one places: * > It could appear in [> sereis-treemap][2]> , indicating the unified setting of the series.

* > It could appear in each array element of [> series-treemap.levels][1]> , indicating the unified setting of each level of the tree.

* > It could appear in each node of [> series-treemap.data][0]> , indicating the particular setting of each node.

colorMappingBy.desc:
Specify the rule according to which each node obtain color from [color list][0]. Optional values: 

* 'value':

Map [series-treemap.data.value][1] to color. In this way, the color of each node indicate its value. [visualDimension][2] can be used to specify which dimension of [data][3] is used to perform visual mapping. 

* 'index':

Map the index (ordinal number) of nodes to color. Namely, in a level, the first node is mapped to the first color of [color list][0], and the second node gets the second color. In this way, adjacent nodes are distinguished by color. 

* 'id':

Map [series-treemap.data.id][4] to color. Since id is used to identify node, if user call setOption to modify the tree, each node will remain the original color before and after setOption called. See this [example][5]. About visual encoding, see details in [series-treemap.levels][6]. 

> Tps: In treemap, > colorMappingBy>  attribute could appear in more than one places: * > It could appear in [> sereis-treemap][7]> , indicating the unified setting of the series.

* > It could appear in each array element of [> series-treemap.levels][6]> , indicating the unified setting of each level of the tree.

* > It could appear in each node of [> series-treemap.data][3]> , indicating the particular setting of each node.

visibleMin.desc:
A node will not be shown when its area size is smaller than this value (unit: px square). In this way, tiny nodes will be hidden, otherwise they will huddle together. When user zoom the treemap, the area size will increase and the rectangle will be shown if the area size is larger than this threshold. About visual encoding, see details in [series-treemap.levels][0]. 

> Tps: In treemap, > visibleMin>  attribute could appear in more than one places: * > It could appear in [> sereis-treemap][1]> , indicating the unified setting of the series.

label.rich.<style_name>.width.desc: Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

label.rich.<style_name>.height.desc: Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

upperLabel.desc:
upperLabel is used to specify whether show label when the node has children. When [upperLabel.show][0] is set as true, the feature that "show parent label" is enabled. The same as [series-treemap.label][1], the option upperLabel can be placed at the root of [series-treemap][2] directly, or in [series-treemap.level][3], or in each item of [series-treemap.data][4]. Specifically, [series-treemap.label][1] specifies the style when a node is a leaf, while upperLabel specifies the style when a node has children, in which case the label is displayed in the inner top of the node. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

itemStyle.desc:
>  Tps: In treemap, > itemStyle>  attribute could appear in more than one places: * > It could appear in [> sereis-treemap][0]> , indicating the unified setting of the series.

* > It could appear in each array element of [> series-treemap.levels][1]> , indicating the unified setting of each level of the tree.

* > It could appear in each node of [> series-treemap.data][2]> , indicating the particular setting of each node.



[0]: #series-treemap
[1]: #series-treemap.levels
[2]: #series-treemap.data

itemStyle.color.desc:
The color of a node. It use global palette [option.color][0] by default.

[0]: #color

itemStyle.colorAlpha.desc: The tranparent rate of a node, the range is between 0 ~ 1.

itemStyle.colorSaturation.desc: The color saturation of a node. The range is between 0 ~ 1.

itemStyle.borderWidth.desc:
The border width of a node. There is no border when it is set as 0. Tip, gaps between child nodes are specified by [gapWidth][0]

[0]: #series-treemap.levels.gapWidth

itemStyle.borderColor.desc: The border color and gap color of a node.

itemStyle.borderColorSaturation.desc:
The color saturation of a border or gap. The value range is between 0 ~ 1. Tips: When borderColorSaturation is set, the borderColor is disabled, and, instead, the final border color is calculated based on the color of this node (this color could be sepcified explicitly or inherited from its parent node) and mixing with borderColorSaturation. In this way, a effect can be implemented: different sections have different hue of gap color repectively, which makes users easy to distinguish both sections and levels. **How to avoid confusion by setting border/gap of node** If all of the border/gaps are set with the same color, confusion might occur when rectangulars in different levels display at the same time. See the [example][0]. Notice that the child rectangles in the red area are in the deeper level than rectangles that are saparated by white gap. So in the red area, basically we set gap color with red, and use borderColorSaturation to lift the saturation.

[0]: https://echarts.apache.org/examples/en/editor.html?c=doc-example/treemap-borderColor&edit=1&reset=1

itemStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as color.

itemStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

itemStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

itemStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

itemStyle.decal.desc:
The style of the decal pattern. It works only if [aria.enabled][0] and [aria.decal.show][1] are both set to be true. If it is set to be 'none', no decal will be used.

[0]: #aria.enabled
[1]: #aria.decal.show

itemStyle.decal.symbol.desc:
The symbol type of the decal. If it is in the type of string[], it means the symbols are used one by one. Icon types provided by ECharts includes 'circle', 'rect', 'roundRect', 'triangle', 'diamond', 'pin', 'arrow', 'none' It can be set to an image with 'image://url' , in which URL is the link to an image, or dataURI of an image. An image URL example: 

    'image://http://xxx.xxx.xxx/a/b.png'
    

A dataURI example: 

    'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'
    

Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via 'path://' in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to [SVG PathData][0] for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe For example: 

    'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'
    

[0]: http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/paths.html#PathData

itemStyle.decal.symbolSize.desc: Range of values: 0 to 1, representing the size of symbol relative to decal.

itemStyle.decal.symbolKeepAspect.desc: Whether or not to keep the aspect ratio of the pattern.

itemStyle.decal.color.desc: For the color of the decal pattern, it is recommended to use a translucent color, which can be superimposed on the color of the series itself.

itemStyle.decal.backgroundColor.desc: The background color of the decal will be over the color of the series itself, under the decal pattern.

itemStyle.decal.dashArrayX.desc:
The basic pattern of the decal pattern is an infinite loop in the form of Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank both horizontally and vertically, respectively. By setting the length of each pattern and blank, complex pattern effects can be achieved. dashArrayX controls the horizontal pattern pattern. When its value is of type number or number[], it is similar to [SVG stroke-dasharray][0]. 

* If it is of type number, it means that the pattern and the blank space are of this value respectively. For example, 5 means the pattern with width 5 is displayed first, then 5 pixels empty, then the pattern with width 5 is displayed...
* In the case of number[] type, it means that the pattern and empty space are loops of an array of values. For example: [5, 10, 2, 6] means the pattern is 5 pixels wide, then 10 pixels empty, then the pattern is 2 pixels wide, then 6 pixels empty, then the pattern is 5 pixels wide...
* If of type (number | number[])[], it means that each row is a loop with an array of values for the pattern and blank space. For example: [10, [2, 5]] means that the first line will be 10 pixels by 10 pixels and empty space, the second line will be 2 pixels by 2 pixels and empty space, and the third line will be 10 pixels by 10 pixels and empty space...

This interface can be better understood with the following examples. 暂时无法显示

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray

itemStyle.decal.dashArrayY.desc:
The basic pattern of the decal pattern is an infinite loop in the form of Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank both horizontally and vertically, respectively. By setting the length of each pattern and blank, complex pattern effects can be achieved. dashArrayY controls the horizontal pattern pattern. Similar to [SVG stroke-dasharray][0]. 

* If it is a number type, it means the pattern and the blank are each of this value. For example, 5 means that the pattern with a height of 5 is displayed first, then 5 pixels empty, then the pattern with a height of 5 is displayed...
* In the case of number[] type, it means that the pattern and empty space are loops of sequential array values. For example: [5, 10, 2, 6] means the pattern is 5 pixels high, then 10 pixels empty, then the pattern is 2 pixels high, then 6 pixels empty, then the pattern is 5 pixels high...

This interface can be better understood with the following examples. 暂时无法显示

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray

itemStyle.decal.rotation.desc: The overall rotation angle (in radians) of the pattern, in the range from `-Math.

itemStyle.decal.maxTileWidth.desc: The upper limit of the width of the generated pattern before it is duplicated. Usually this value is not necessary, but you can try to increase it if you notice discontinuous seams in the pattern when it repeats.

itemStyle.decal.maxTileHeight.desc: The upper limit of the height of the generated pattern before it repeats. This value is usually not necessary to set, but you can try to increase it if you find that the pattern has discontinuous seams when it is repeated.

emphasis.focus.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 When the data is highlighted, whether to fade out of other data to focus the highlighted. The following configurations are supported: 

* 'none' Do not fade out other data, it's by default.
* 'self' Only focus (not fade out) the element of the currently highlighted data.

* 'series' Focus on all elements of the series which the currently highlighted data belongs to.

* 'ancestor' Focus on all ancestor nodes.
* 'descendant' Focus on all descendants nodes.

**Example:**    emphasis: {
        focus: 'series',
        blurScope: 'coordinateSystem'
    }

>  Since > v5.0.0 To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are: 

* 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
* 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
* 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN [lineCap][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap

emphasis.labelLine.lineStyle.join.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet. Possible values are: 

* 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
* 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
* 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the miterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN [lineJoin][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin

emphasis.labelLine.lineStyle.miterLimit.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when join is set as miter. Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored. Refer to MDN [miterLimit][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit

blur.labelLine.lineStyle.cap.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are: 

* 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
* 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
* 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN [lineCap][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap

blur.labelLine.lineStyle.join.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet. Possible values are: 

* 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
* 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
* 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the miterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN [lineJoin][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin

blur.labelLine.lineStyle.miterLimit.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when join is set as miter. Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored. Refer to MDN [miterLimit][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit

select.label.offset.desc: Whether to move text slightly. For example: [30, 40] means move 30 horizontally and move 40 vertically.

select.label.color.desc: text color. If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

select.label.borderColor.desc: Border color of the text fragment. If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

select.label.borderWidth.desc: Border width of the text fragment.

select.label.borderType.desc:
the text fragment border type. Possible values are: 

* 'solid'
* 'dashed'
* 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array][0] of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible. For example： 

    {
    
    borderType: [5, 10],
    
    borderDashOffset: 5
    }
    



[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray

* padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
* padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

select.label.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when width is set. 

* 'truncate' Truncate the text and trailing with ellipsis.
* 'break' Break by word
* 'breakAll' Break by character.

select.label.rich.<style_name>.width.desc: Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

select.label.rich.<style_name>.height.desc: Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see backgroundColor). select.labelLine.lineStyle.cap.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are: 

* 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
* 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
* 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN [lineCap][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap

select.labelLine.lineStyle.join.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet. Possible values are: 

* 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
* 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
* 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the miterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN [lineJoin][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin

select.labelLine.lineStyle.miterLimit.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when join is set as miter. Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored. Refer to MDN [miterLimit][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit

select.labelLine.lineStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

selectedMode.desc: >  Since > v5.0.0 Selected mode. It is enabled by default, and you may set it to be false to disabled it. Besides, it can be set to 'single' or 'multiple', for single selection and multiple selections.

breadcrumb.desc: breadcrumb, showing the path of the current node.

breadcrumb.left.desc: Distance between asdf component and the left side of the container. left value can be instant pixel value like 20; it can also be a percentage value relative to container width like '20%'; and it can also be 'left', 'center', or 'right'. If the left value is set to be 'left', 'center', or 'right', then the component will be aligned automatically based on position.

breadcrumb.top.desc: Distance between asdf component and the top side of the container. top value can be instant pixel value like 20; it can also be a percentage value relative to container width like '20%'; and it can also be 'top', 'middle', or 'bottom'. If the left value is set to be 'top', 'middle', or 'bottom', then the component will be aligned automatically based on position.

breadcrumb.right.desc: Distance between asdf component and the right side of the container. right value can be instant pixel value like 20; it can also be a percentage value relative to container width like '20%'. Adaptive by default.

breadcrumb.bottom.desc: Distance between asdf component and the bottom side of the container. bottom value can be instant pixel value like 20; it can also be a percentage value relative to container width like '20%'. Adaptive by default.

breadcrumb.emptyItemWidth.desc: When is no content in breadcrumb, this minimal width need to be set up.

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array][0] of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible. For example：

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset

breadcrumb.emphasis.itemStyle.borderCap.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are: 

* 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
* 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
* 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN [lineCap][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap

breadcrumb.emphasis.itemStyle.borderJoin.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet. Possible values are: 

* 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
* 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
* 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the borderMiterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN [lineJoin][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin

breadcrumb.emphasis.itemStyle.borderMite.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when borderJoin is set as miter. Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored. Refer to MDN [miterLimit][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit

labelLayout.hideOverlap.desc: If hide the overlapped labels. The following example shows how to hide the overlapped labels in graph automatically when zooming. 暂时无法显示

labelLayout.moveOverlap.desc:
If move the overlapped labels to avoid overlapping. Currently supported configurations: 

* 'shiftX' Place the labels on horizontal direction sequencely, used when aligned horizontally.
* 'shiftY' Place the labels on vertial direction sequencely, used when aligned vertically.

The following example shows how to use moverOverlap: 'shiftY' to place the labels aligned vertically. 暂时无法显示

labelLayout.x.desc: The x position of the label. Support absolute pixel values ​​or relative values ​​such as '20%'.

labelLayout.y.desc: The y position of the label. Support absolute pixel values ​​or relative values ​​such as '20%'.

labelLayout.dx.desc: The pixel offset of the label in the x direction. Can be used with x.

labelLayout.dy.desc: The pixel offset of the label in the y direction. Can be used with y

labelLayout.width.desc: The width of displayed label. Can be used with overflow to constraint the label in a fixed width

labelLayout.height.desc: The height of displayed label. Can be used with lineOverflow to constraint the label in a fixed height.

labelLayout.align.desc: The horizontal alignment of the label. Can be 'left', 'center', 'right'.

labelLayout.verticalAlign.desc: The vertical alignment of the label. Can be 'top', 'middle', 'bottom'.

labelLayout.fontSize.desc: The text size of the label.

labelLayout.draggable.desc: Whether to allow the user to adjust the position by dragging.

labelLayout.labelLinePoints.desc:
The array of the three points of the label guide line. The format is: 

    [[x, y], [x, y], [x, y]]
    

It is often used in pie charts to fine-tune the guide line that has been calculated. Usually not recommended to set it in other situations.

levels.visualDimension.desc:
treemap is able to map any dimensions of data to visual. The value of [series-treemap.data][0] can be an array. And each item of the array represents a "dimension". visualDimension specifies the dimension on which visual mapping will be performed. About visual encoding, see details in [series-treemap.levels][1]. 

> Tps: In treemap, > visualDimension>  attribute could appear in more than one places: * > It could appear in [> sereis-treemap][2]> , indicating the unified setting of the series.

* > It could appear in each array element of [> series-treemap.levels][1]> , indicating the unified setting of each level of the tree.

* > It could appear in each node of [> series-treemap.data][0]> , indicating the particular setting of each node.



[0]: #series-treemap.data
[1]: #series-treemap.levels
[2]: #series-treemap

levels.visualMin.desc:
The minimal value of current level. Auto-statistics by default. When [colorMappingBy][0] is set to 'value', you are able to specify extent manually for visual mapping by specifying visualMin or visualMax.

[0]: #series-treemap.levels.colorMappingBy

levels.visualMax.desc:
The maximal value of current level. Auto-statistics by default. When [colorMappingBy][0] is set to 'value', you are able to specify extent manually for visual mapping by specifying visualMin or visualMax.

[0]: #series-treemap.levels.colorMappingBy

levels.color.desc:
A color list for a level. Each node in the level will obtain a color from the color list (the rule see [colorMappingBy][0]). It is empty by default, which means the global color list will be used. About visual encoding, see details in [series-treemap.levels][1]. 

> Tps: In treemap, > color>  attribute could appear in more than one places: * > It could appear in each array element of [> series-treemap.levels][1]> , indicating the unified setting of each level of the tree.

* > It could appear in each node of [> series-treemap.data][2]> , indicating the particular setting of each node.



[0]: #series-treemap.levels.colorMappingBy
[1]: #series-treemap.levels
[2]: #series-treemap.data

levels.colorAlpha.desc:
It indicates the range of tranparent rate (color alpha) for nodes in a level . The range of values is 0 ~ 1. For example, colorAlpha can be [0.3, 1]. About visual encoding, see details in [series-treemap.levels][0]. 

> Tps: In treemap, > colorAlpha>  attribute could appear in more than one places: * > It could appear in [> sereis-treemap][1]> , indicating the unified setting of the series.

* > It could appear in each array element of [> series-treemap.levels][0]> , indicating the unified setting of each level of the tree.

* > It could appear in each node of [> series-treemap.data][2]> , indicating the particular setting of each node.



[0]: #series-treemap.levels
[1]: #series-treemap
[2]: #series-treemap.data

levels.colorSaturation.desc:
It indicates the range of saturation (color alpha) for nodes in a level. The range of values is 0 ~ 1. For example, colorSaturation can be [0.3, 1]. About visual encoding, see details in [series-treemap.levels][0]. 

> Tps: In treemap, > colorSaturation>  attribute could appear in more than one places: * > It could appear in [> sereis-treemap][1]> , indicating the unified setting of the series.

* > It could appear in each array element of [> series-treemap.levels][0]> , indicating the unified setting of each level of the tree.

* > It could appear in each node of [> series-treemap.data][2]> , indicating the particular setting of each node.



[0]: #series-treemap.levels
[1]: #series-treemap
[2]: #series-treemap.data

levels.colorMappingBy.desc:
Specify the rule according to which each node obtain color from [color list][0]. Optional values: 

* 'value':

Map [series-treemap.data.value][1] to color. In this way, the color of each node indicate its value. [visualDimension][2] can be used to specify which dimension of [data][3] is used to perform visual mapping. 

* 'index':

Map the index (ordinal number) of nodes to color. Namely, in a level, the first node is mapped to the first color of [color list][0], and the second node gets the second color. In this way, adjacent nodes are distinguished by color. 

* 'id':

Map [series-treemap.data.id][4] to color. Since id is used to identify node, if user call setOption to modify the tree, each node will remain the original color before and after setOption called. See this [example][5]. About visual encoding, see details in [series-treemap.levels][6]. 

> Tps: In treemap, > colorMappingBy>  attribute could appear in more than one places: * > It could appear in [> sereis-treemap][7]> , indicating the unified setting of the series.

* > It could appear in each array element of [> series-treemap.levels][6]> , indicating the unified setting of each level of the tree.

* > It could appear in each node of [> series-treemap.data][3]> , indicating the particular setting of each node.



[0]: #series-treemap.levels.color
[1]: #series-treemap.data.value
[2]: #series-treemap.levels.visualDimension
[3]: #series-treemap.data
[4]: #series-treemap.data.id
[5]: https://echarts.apache.org/examples/en/editor.html?c=treemap-obama&edit=1&reset=1
[6]: #series-treemap.levels
[7]: #series-treemap

levels.visibleMin.desc:
A node will not be shown when its area size is smaller than this value (unit: px square). In this way, tiny nodes will be hidden, otherwise they will huddle together. When user zoom the treemap, the area size will increase and the rectangle will be shown if the area size is larger than this threshold. About visual encoding, see details in [series-treemap.levels][0]. 

> Tps: In treemap, > visibleMin>  attribute could appear in more than one places: * > It could appear in [> sereis-treemap][1]> , indicating the unified setting of the series.

* > It could appear in each array element of [> series-treemap.levels][0]> , indicating the unified setting of each level of the tree.

* > It could appear in each node of [> series-treemap.data][2]> , indicating the particular setting of each node.



[0]: #series-treemap.levels
[1]: #series-treemap
[2]: #series-treemap.data

levels.childrenVisibleMin.desc:
Children will not be shown when area size of a node is smaller than this value (unit: px square). This can hide the details of nodes when the rectangular area is not large enough. When users zoom nodes, the child node would show if the area is larger than this threshold. About visual encoding, see details in [series-treemap.levels][0]. 

> Tps: In treemap, > childrenVisibleMin>  attribute could appear in more than one places: * > It could appear in [> sereis-treemap][1]> , indicating the unified setting of the series.

* > It could appear in each array element of [> series-treemap.levels][0]> , indicating the unified setting of each level of the tree.

* > It could appear in each node of [> series-treemap.data][2]> , indicating the particular setting of each node.

[2]: #series-treemap.data

levels.upperLabel.desc:
upperLabel is used to specify whether show label when the node has children. When [upperLabel.show][0] is set as true, the feature that "show parent label" is enabled. The same as [series-treemap.label][1], the option upperLabel can be placed at the root of [series-treemap][2] directly, or in [series-treemap.level][3], or in each item of [series-treemap.data][4]. Specifically, [series-treemap.label][1] specifies the style when a node is a leaf, while upperLabel specifies the style when a node has children, in which case the label is displayed in the inner top of the node. See: 暂时无法显示 

> Tps: In treemap, > label>  attribute could appear in more than one places: * > It could appear in [> sereis-treemap][2]> , indicating the unified setting of the series.

* > It could appear in each array element of [> series-treemap.levels][5]> , indicating the unified setting of each level of the tree.

* > It could appear in each node of [> series-treemap.data][4]> , indicating the particular setting of each node.

levels.itemStyle.color.desc:
The color of a node. It use global palette [option.color][0] by default.

[0]: #color

levels.itemStyle.colorAlpha.desc: The tranparent rate of a node, the range is between 0 ~ 1.

levels.itemStyle.colorSaturation.desc: The color saturation of a node. The range is between 0 ~ 1.

levels.itemStyle.borderWidth.desc:
The border width of a node. There is no border when it is set as 0. Tip, gaps between child nodes are specified by [gapWidth][0]

[0]: #series-treemap.levels.gapWidth

levels.itemStyle.borderColor.desc: The border color and gap color of a node.

levels.itemStyle.borderColorSaturation.desc:
The color saturation of a border or gap. The value range is between 0 ~ 1. Tips: When borderColorSaturation is set, the borderColor is disabled, and, instead, the final border color is calculated based on the color of this node (this color could be sepcified explicitly or inherited from its parent node) and mixing with borderColorSaturation. In this way, a effect can be implemented: different sections have different hue of gap color repectively, which makes users easy to distinguish both sections and levels. **How to avoid confusion by setting border/gap of node** If all of the border/gaps are set with the same color, confusion might occur when rectangulars in different levels display at the same time. See the [example][0]. Notice that the child rectangles in the red area are in the deeper level than rectangles that are saparated by white gap. So in the red area, basically we set gap color with red, and use borderColorSaturation to lift the saturation.

[0]: https://echarts.apache.org/examples/en/editor.html?c=doc-example/treemap-borderColor&edit=1&reset=1

levels.itemStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

The style of the decal pattern. It works only if [aria.enabled][0] and [aria.decal.show][1] are both set to be true. If it is set to be 'none', no decal will be used.

[0]: #aria.enabled
[1]: #aria.decal.show

levels.itemStyle.decal.symbol.desc:
The symbol type of the decal. If it is in the type of string[], it means the symbols are used one by one. Icon types provided by ECharts includes 'circle', 'rect', 'roundRect', 'triangle', 'diamond', 'pin', 'arrow', 'none' It can be set to an image with 'image://url' , in which URL is the link to an image, or dataURI of an image. An image URL example: 

    'image://http://xxx.xxx.xxx/a/b.png'
    

A dataURI example: 

    'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'
    

Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via 'path://' in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to [SVG PathData][0] for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe For example: 

    'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'
    

[0]: http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/paths.html#PathData

levels.itemStyle.decal.symbolSize.desc: Range of values: 0 to 1, representing the size of symbol relative to decal.

levels.itemStyle.decal.symbolKeepAspect.desc: Whether or not to keep the aspect ratio of the pattern.

levels.itemStyle.decal.color.desc: For the color of the decal pattern, it is recommended to use a translucent color, which can be superimposed on the color of the series itself.

levels.itemStyle.decal.backgroundColor.desc: The background color of the decal will be over the color of the series itself, under the decal pattern.

levels.itemStyle.decal.dashArrayX.desc:
The basic pattern of the decal pattern is an infinite loop in the form of Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank both horizontally and vertically, respectively. By setting the length of each pattern and blank, complex pattern effects can be achieved. dashArrayX controls the horizontal pattern pattern. When its value is of type number or number[], it is similar to [SVG stroke-dasharray][0]. 

* If it is of type number, it means that the pattern and the blank space are of this value respectively. For example, 5 means the pattern with width 5 is displayed first, then 5 pixels empty, then the pattern with width 5 is displayed...
* In the case of number[] type, it means that the pattern and empty space are loops of an array of values. For example: [5, 10, 2, 6] means the pattern is 5 pixels wide, then 10 pixels empty, then the pattern is 2 pixels wide, then 6 pixels empty, then the pattern is 5 pixels wide...
* If of type (number | number[])[], it means that each row is a loop with an array of values for the pattern and blank space. For example: [10, [2, 5]] means that the first line will be 10 pixels by 10 pixels and empty space, the second line will be 2 pixels by 2 pixels and empty space, and the third line will be 10 pixels by 10 pixels and empty space...

This interface can be better understood with the following examples. 暂时无法显示

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray

levels.itemStyle.decal.dashArrayY.desc:
The basic pattern of the decal pattern is an infinite loop in the form of Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank both horizontally and vertically, respectively. By setting the length of each pattern and blank, complex pattern effects can be achieved. dashArrayY controls the horizontal pattern pattern. Similar to [SVG stroke-dasharray][0]. 

* If it is a number type, it means the pattern and the blank are each of this value. For example, 5 means that the pattern with a height of 5 is displayed first, then 5 pixels empty, then the pattern with a height of 5 is displayed...
* In the case of number[] type, it means that the pattern and empty space are loops of sequential array values. For example: [5, 10, 2, 6] means the pattern is 5 pixels high, then 10 pixels empty, then the pattern is 2 pixels high, then 6 pixels empty, then the pattern is 5 pixels high...

This interface can be better understood with the following examples. 暂时无法显示

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray

levels.itemStyle.decal.rotation.desc: The overall rotation angle (in radians) of the pattern, in the range from `-Math.

levels.itemStyle.decal.maxTileWidth.desc: The upper limit of the width of the generated pattern before it is duplicated. Usually this value is not necessary, but you can try to increase it if you notice discontinuous seams in the pattern when it repeats.

levels.itemStyle.decal.maxTileHeight.desc: The upper limit of the height of the generated pattern before it repeats. This value is usually not necessary to set, but you can try to increase it if you find that the pattern has discontinuous seams when it is repeated.

levels.emphasis.label.position.desc:

      // Absolute pixel values
      position: [10, 10],
      // Relative percentage
      position: ['50%', '50%']

levels.emphasis.label.borderType.desc:
the text fragment border type. Possible values are: 

* 'solid'
* 'dashed'
* 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array][0] of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible. For example：

levels.emphasis.labelLine.lineStyle.cap.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are: 

* 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
* 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
* 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN [lineCap][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap

levels.emphasis.labelLine.lineStyle.join.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet. Possible values are: 

* 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
* 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
* 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the miterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN [lineJoin][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin

levels.emphasis.labelLine.lineStyle.mite.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when join is set as miter. Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored. Refer to MDN [miterLimit][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit

levels.blur.label.rich.<style_name>.widt.desc: Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

levels.blur.label.rich.<style_name>.heig.desc: Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. levels.blur.labelLine.lineStyle.cap.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are: 

* 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
* 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
* 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN [lineCap][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap

levels.blur.labelLine.lineStyle.join.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet. Possible values are: 

* 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
* 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
* 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the miterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN [lineJoin][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin

levels.blur.labelLine.lineStyle.miterLim.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when join is set as miter. Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored. Refer to MDN [miterLimit][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit

data.visualDimension.desc:
treemap is able to map any dimensions of data to visual. The value of [series-treemap.data][0] can be an array. And each item of the array represents a "dimension". visualDimension specifies the dimension on which visual mapping will be performed. About visual encoding, see details in [series-treemap.levels][1].

* > It could appear in each node of [> series-treemap.data][0]> , indicating the particular setting of each node.

data.colorMappingBy.desc:
Specify the rule according to which each node obtain color from [color list][0]. Optional values: 

* 'value':

Map [series-treemap.data.value][1] to color. In this way, the color of each node indicate its value. [visualDimension][2] can be used to specify which dimension of [data][3] is used to perform visual mapping. 

* 'index':

Map the index (ordinal number) of nodes to color. Namely, in a level, the first node is mapped to the first color of [color list][0], and the second node gets the second color. In this way, adjacent nodes are distinguished by color. 

* 'id':

Map [series-treemap.data.id][4] to color. Since id is used to identify node, if user call setOption to modify the tree, each node will remain the original color before and after setOption called. See this [example][5]. About visual encoding, see details in [series-treemap.levels][6]. 

> Tps: In treemap, > colorMappingBy>  attribute could appear in more than one places: * > It could appear in [> sereis-treemap][7]> , indicating the unified setting of the series.

* > It could appear in each array element of [> series-treemap.levels][6]> , indicating the unified setting of each level of the tree.

* > It could appear in each node of [> series-treemap.data][3]> , indicating the particular setting of each node.

upperLabel is used to specify whether show label when the node has children. When [upperLabel.show][0] is set as true, the feature that "show parent label" is enabled. Specifically, [series-treemap.label][1] specifies the style when a node is a leaf, while upperLabel specifies the style when a node has children, in which case the label is displayed in the inner top of the node. data.itemStyle.desc:
>  Tps: In treemap, > itemStyle>  attribute could appear in more than one places: * > It could appear in [> sereis-treemap][0]> , indicating the unified setting of the series.

* > It could appear in each array element of [> series-treemap.levels][1]> , indicating the unified setting of each level of the tree.

* > It could appear in each node of [> series-treemap.data][2]> , indicating the particular setting of each node.



[0]: #series-treemap
[1]: #series-treemap.levels
[2]: #series-treemap.data

data.itemStyle.color.desc:
The color of a node. It use global palette [option.color][0] by default.

[0]: #color

data.itemStyle.colorAlpha.desc: The tranparent rate of a node, the range is between 0 ~ 1.

data.itemStyle.colorSaturation.desc: The color saturation of a node. The range is between 0 ~ 1.

data.itemStyle.borderWidth.desc:
The border width of a node. There is no border when it is set as 0. Tip, gaps between child nodes are specified by [gapWidth][0]

[0]: #series-treemap.levels.gapWidth

data.itemStyle.borderColor.desc: The border color and gap color of a node.

data.itemStyle.borderColorSaturation.desc:
The color saturation of a border or gap. The value range is between 0 ~ 1. Tips: When borderColorSaturation is set, the borderColor is disabled, and, instead, the final border color is calculated based on the color of this node (this color could be sepcified explicitly or inherited from its parent node) and mixing with borderColorSaturation. In this way, a effect can be implemented: different sections have different hue of gap color repectively, which makes users easy to distinguish both sections and levels. **How to avoid confusion by setting border/gap of node** If all of the border/gaps are set with the same color, confusion might occur when rectangulars in different levels display at the same time. See the [example][0]. Notice that the child rectangles in the red area are in the deeper level than rectangles that are saparated by white gap. So in the red area, basically we set gap color with red, and use borderColorSaturation to lift the saturation.

[0]: https://echarts.apache.org/examples/en/editor.html?c=doc-example/treemap-borderColor&edit=1&reset=1

data.itemStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as color.

data.itemStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

data.itemStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

data.itemStyle.decal.desc:
The style of the decal pattern. It works only if [aria.enabled][0] and [aria.decal.show][1] are both set to be true. If it is set to be 'none', no decal will be used.

[0]: #aria.enabled
[1]: #aria.decal.show

data.itemStyle.decal.symbol.desc:
The symbol type of the decal. If it is in the type of string[], it means the symbols are used one by one. Icon types provided by ECharts includes 'circle', 'rect', 'roundRect', 'triangle', 'diamond', 'pin', 'arrow', 'none' It can be set to an image with 'image://url' , in which URL is the link to an image, or dataURI of an image. An image URL example: 

    'image://http://xxx.xxx.xxx/a/b.png'
    

A dataURI example: 

    'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'
    

Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via 'path://' in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to [SVG PathData][0] for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe For example: 

    'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'
    

[0]: http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/paths.html#PathData

data.itemStyle.decal.symbolSize.desc: Range of values: 0 to 1, representing the size of symbol relative to decal.

data.itemStyle.decal.symbolKeepAspect.desc: Whether or not to keep the aspect ratio of the pattern.

data.itemStyle.decal.color.desc: For the color of the decal pattern, it is recommended to use a translucent color, which can be superimposed on the color of the series itself.

data.itemStyle.decal.backgroundColor.desc: The background color of the decal will be over the color of the series itself, under the decal pattern.

data.itemStyle.decal.dashArrayX.desc:
The basic pattern of the decal pattern is an infinite loop in the form of Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank both horizontally and vertically, respectively. By setting the length of each pattern and blank, complex pattern effects can be achieved. dashArrayX controls the horizontal pattern pattern. When its value is of type number or number[], it is similar to [SVG stroke-dasharray][0]. 

* If it is of type number, it means that the pattern and the blank space are of this value respectively. For example, 5 means the pattern with width 5 is displayed first, then 5 pixels empty, then the pattern with width 5 is displayed...
* In the case of number[] type, it means that the pattern and empty space are loops of an array of values. For example: [5, 10, 2, 6] means the pattern is 5 pixels wide, then 10 pixels empty, then the pattern is 2 pixels wide, then 6 pixels empty, then the pattern is 5 pixels wide...
* If of type (number | number[])[], it means that each row is a loop with an array of values for the pattern and blank space. For example: [10, [2, 5]] means that the first line will be 10 pixels by 10 pixels and empty space, the second line will be 2 pixels by 2 pixels and empty space, and the third line will be 10 pixels by 10 pixels and empty space...

This interface can be better understood with the following examples. 暂时无法显示

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray

data.itemStyle.decal.dashArrayY.desc:
The basic pattern of the decal pattern is an infinite loop in the form of Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank both horizontally and vertically, respectively. By setting the length of each pattern and blank, complex pattern effects can be achieved. dashArrayY controls the horizontal pattern pattern. Similar to [SVG stroke-dasharray][0]. 

* If it is a number type, it means the pattern and the blank are each of this value. For example, 5 means that the pattern with a height of 5 is displayed first, then 5 pixels empty, then the pattern with a height of 5 is displayed...
* In the case of number[] type, it means that the pattern and empty space are loops of sequential array values. For example: [5, 10, 2, 6] means the pattern is 5 pixels high, then 10 pixels empty, then the pattern is 2 pixels high, then 6 pixels empty, then the pattern is 5 pixels high...

This interface can be better understood with the following examples. 暂时无法显示

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray

data.itemStyle.decal.maxTileWidth.desc: The upper limit of the width of the generated pattern before it is duplicated. Usually this value is not necessary, but you can try to increase it if you notice discontinuous seams in the pattern when it repeats.

data.itemStyle.decal.maxTileHeight.desc: The upper limit of the height of the generated pattern before it repeats. This value is usually not necessary to set, but you can try to increase it if you find that the pattern has discontinuous seams when it is repeated.

>  Since > v5.0.0 To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are: 

* 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.

* 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

data.blur.upperLabel.rich.<style_name>.w.desc: Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

data.select.labelLine.lineStyle.cap.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are: 

* 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
* 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
* 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN [lineCap][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap

data.select.labelLine.lineStyle.join.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet. Possible values are: 

* 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
* 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
* 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the miterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN [lineJoin][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin

data.select.labelLine.lineStyle.miterLim.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when join is set as miter. Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored. Refer to MDN [miterLimit][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit

data.tooltip.desc: tooltip settings in this series data.

data.tooltip.position.desc:
提示框浮层的位置，默认不设置时位置会跟随鼠标的位置。

可选：

* Array

通过数组表示提示框浮层的位置，支持数字设置绝对位置，百分比设置相对位置。

示例:
```javascript
// 绝对位置，相对于容器左侧 10px, 上侧 10 px
position: [10, 10]
// 相对位置，放置在容器正中间
position: ['50%', '50%']
```

* Function

回调函数，格式如下：

```javascript
(point: Array, params: Object|Array.<Object>, dom: HTMLDomElement, rect: Object, size: Object) => Array
```

**参数**
point: 鼠标位置，如 [20, 40]。
params: 同 formatter 的参数相同。
dom: tooltip 的 dom 对象。
rect: 只有鼠标在图形上时有效，是一个用 x , y , width , height四个属性表达的图形包围盒。
size: 包括 dom 的尺寸和 echarts 容器的当前尺寸，例如：{contentSize: [width, height], viewSize: [width, height]}。

**返回值：**
可以是一个表示 tooltip 位置的数组，数组值可以是绝对的像素值，也可以是相 百分比。
也可以是一个对象，如：{left: 10, top: 30}，或者 {right: '20%', bottom: 40}。

如下示例：

```javascript
position: function (point, params, dom, rect, size) {
    // 固定在顶部
    return [point[0], '10%'];
}
```

或者：

```javascript
position: function (pos, params, dom, rect, size) {
    // 鼠标在左侧时 tooltip 显示到右侧，鼠标在右侧时 tooltip 显示到左侧。
    var obj = {top: 60};
    obj[['left', 'right'][+(pos[0] < size.viewSize[0] / 2)]] = 5;
    return obj;
}
```

* 'inside'
    鼠标所在图形的内部中心位置，只在 trigger 为 'item' 的时候有效。

* 'top'
    鼠标所在图形上侧，只在 trigger 为 'item' 的时候有效。

* 'left'
    鼠标所在图形左侧，只在 trigger 为 'item' 的时候有效。

* 'right'
    鼠标所在图形右侧，只在 trigger 为 'item' 的时候有效。

* 'bottom'
    鼠标所在图形底侧，只在 trigger 为 'item' 的时候有效。

The background color of tooltip's floating layer.

The border color of tooltip's floating layer.

[0]: #tooltip.trigger

data.tooltip.borderWidth.desc:
**> Notice：**> series.data.tooltip only works when [> tooltip.trigger][0]>  is > 'item'> .  
The border width of tooltip's floating layer.

[0]: #tooltip.trigger

data.tooltip.padding.desc:
**> Notice：**> series.data.tooltip only works when [> tooltip.trigger][0]>  is > 'item'> .  
The floating layer of tooltip space around content. The unit is px. Default values for each position are 5. And they can be set to different values with left, right, top, and bottom. Examples: 

    // Set padding to be 5
    padding: 5
    // Set the top and bottom paddings to be 5, and left and right paddings to be 10
    padding: [5, 10]
    // Set each of the four paddings seperately
    padding: [
        5,  // up
        10, // right
        5,  // down
        10, // left
    ]
    



[0]: #tooltip.trigger

data.tooltip.textStyle.desc:
**> Notice：**> series.data.tooltip only works when [> tooltip.trigger][0]>  is > 'item'> .  
The text syle of tooltip's floating layer.

[0]: #tooltip.trigger

data.tooltip.textStyle.textBorderWidth.desc: Storke line width of the text.

data.tooltip.textStyle.textBorderType.desc:
Stroke line type of the text. Possible values are: 

* 'solid'
* 'dashed'
* 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array][0] of the line. With textBorderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible. For example： 

    {
    
    textBorderType: [5, 10],
    
    textBorderDashOffset: 5
    }
    



[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray

data.tooltip.textStyle.textBorderDashOff.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the line dash offset. With textBorderType , we can make the line style more flexible. Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset

data.tooltip.textStyle.textShadowColor.desc: Shadow color of the text itself.

data.tooltip.textStyle.textShadowBlur.desc: Shadow blue of the text itself.

data.tooltip.textStyle.textShadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text itself.

data.tooltip.textStyle.textShadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text itself.

data.tooltip.textStyle.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when width is set. 

* 'truncate' Truncate the text and trailing with ellipsis.
* 'break' Break by word
* 'breakAll' Break by character.

data.tooltip.textStyle.ellipsis.desc: Ellipsis to be displayed when overflow is set to truncate.

data.tooltip.textStyle.lineOverflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow on height. 

* 'truncate' Truncate the overflow lines.

data.tooltip.extraCssText.desc:
**> Notice：**> series.data.tooltip only works when [> tooltip.trigger][0]>  is > 'item'> .  
Extra CSS style for floating layer. The following is an example for adding shadow. 

    extraCssText: 'box-shadow: 0 0 3px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.3);'
    



[0]: #tooltip.trigger

silent.desc: Whether to ignore mouse events. Default value is false, for triggering and responding to mouse events.

animationEasing.desc:
Easing method used for the first animation. Varied easing effects can be found at [easing effect example][0].

[0]: https://echarts.apache.org/examples/en/editor.html?c=line-easing

tooltip.position.desc:
提示框浮层的位置，默认不设置时位置会跟随鼠标的位置。

可选：

* Array

通过数组表示提示框浮层的位置，支持数字设置绝对位置，百分比设置相对位置。

示例:
```javascript
// 绝对位置，相对于容器左侧 10px, 上侧 10 px
position: [10, 10]
// 相对位置，放置在容器正中间
position: ['50%', '50%']
```

* Function

回调函数，格式如下：

```javascript
(point: Array, params: Object|Array.<Object>, dom: HTMLDomElement, rect: Object, size: Object) => Array
```

**参数**
point: 鼠标位置，如 [20, 40]。
params: 同 formatter 的参数相同。
dom: tooltip 的 dom 对象。
rect: 只有鼠标在图形上时有效，是一个用 x , y , width , height四个属性表达的图形包围盒。
size: 包括 dom 的尺寸和 echarts 容器的当前尺寸，例如：{contentSize: [width, height], viewSize: [width, height]}。

**返回值：**
可以是一个表示 tooltip 位置的数组，数组值可以是绝对的像素值，也可以是相 百分比。
也可以是一个对象，如：{left: 10, top: 30}，或者 {right: '20%', bottom: 40}。

如下示例：

```javascript
position: function (point, params, dom, rect, size) {
    // 固定在顶部
    return [point[0], '10%'];
}
```

或者：

```javascript
position: function (pos, params, dom, rect, size) {
    // 鼠标在左侧时 tooltip 显示到右侧，鼠标在右侧时 tooltip 显示到左侧。
    var obj = {top: 60};
    obj[['left', 'right'][+(pos[0] < size.viewSize[0] / 2)]] = 5;
    return obj;
}
```

* 'inside'
    鼠标所在图形的内部中心位置，只在 trigger 为 'item' 的时候有效。

* 'top'
    鼠标所在图形上侧，只在 trigger 为 'item' 的时候有效。

* 'left'
    鼠标所在图形左侧，只在 trigger 为 'item' 的时候有效。

* 'right'
    鼠标所在图形右侧，只在 trigger 为 'item' 的时候有效。

* 'bottom'
    鼠标所在图形底侧，只在 trigger 为 'item' 的时候有效。
